poem:
Autumn Confessions

In the brittle air of October,
a stern voice echoes,
promises lined with barbs.

"We must dismantle the gangs,"
he declares,
but the boats still ferry dreams through dark waters.

Silent hopes,
drifting on the edge,
murmur questions of safe passage.

And the leaves whisper back,
a painful harvest,
as they tumble, unconsoled.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Keir Starmer says autumn budget will be ‘painful’ in Downing Street speech – UK politics live 11.03am BST The press conference is over now. Starmer refused to say whether more safe and legal routes to the UK would be created under his leadership. Asked if safe and legal routes would be extended, he said: So far as stopping the boats is concerned, we have got to take down the gangs that are running the vile". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
